case_vignette: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation. He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago. He is a retired winemaker. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple rough patches on his scalp. A photograph is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having some changes on my scalp skin for about three months, and when I scrape off the crusty part, it just comes back after a few days. Sometimes it itches or burns a bit.
Have you noticed any changes in the color or shape of the affected area on your scalp over these three months?
Yes, the patches on my scalp have been changing.
Are the affected areas on your scalp red, scaly, and with well-defined edges?
The areas are rough, but I'm not sure about the color or edges.
Have you experienced similar skin issues elsewhere on your body, or is it only on your scalp?
I had a mole removed from my right forearm 5 years ago, but that's different from what's happening on my scalp.
Can you describe the mole that was removed and mention if it was benign or malignant?
I don't remember the details about the mole, just that it was removed.
Understood. Do you have a personal or family history of skin conditions like psoriasis, eczema, or seborrheic dermatitis?
The vignette doesn't provide that information.
Is there any flaking or dandruff associated with the patches on your scalp?
It does get crusty.
Have you been using any new hair or skin products, or experienced any significant stress or illness recently?
The vignette doesn't mention anything about that.
Has there been any hair loss in the affected areas of your scalp?
The vignette doesn't say anything about hair loss.
Do you have any associated symptoms such as joint pain, fatigue, or changes in your nails?
No, I don't have any of those symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic dermatitis
